The first sign of genetic hair loss is usually a receding hairline or thinning hair on the crown of the head. Men typically experience hair loss in these areas, while women may notice a widening part or overall thinning of the hair.

  • Bald patches
  • Slow hair growth

Diagnosing Genetic Hair Loss

If you suspect that you have genetic hair loss, it is important to speak with a dermatologist or hair specialist. They will examine your scalp, hair, and medical history to determine the underlying cause of your hair loss.

  • Blood tests to check for hormonal imbalances
  • Scalp biopsy to examine hair follicles under a microscope
  • Trichoscopy to examine the hair and scalp using a special camera

Causes of Genetic Hair Loss

Genetic hair loss is caused by a combination of genetics, hormones, and age. It is thought to be inherited from either the mother or father's side of the family.

The hormone dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is also believed to play a role in genetic hair loss. DHT causes the hair follicles to shrink, which leads to thinning and eventually baldness.

While genetic hair loss cannot be reversed, there are treatments available that may help slow down the process and stimulate new hair growth.

The texture of your hair is determined by the shape of the follicle it grows from. Curly hair grows from follicles that are more oval-shaped, which causes the hair to curl and spiral. What Causes Straight Hair?

Straight hair, on the other hand, grows from follicles that are more circular in shape. This causes the hair to grow straight and smooth. Straight hair tends to be shinier than curly hair because the natural oils produced by the scalp can easily travel down the hair shaft.
